message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest radial nerve palsy, which can occur after trauma or surgery. The area of tenderness and weakness in extending the middle finger suggest that the posterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the radial nerve, is affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the tenderness and weakness in extending the middle finger suggest a radial nerve injury. Among the options, only the posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve and controls the dorsal forearm muscles, including finger extensors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a radial nerve injury, and specifically a posterior interosseous nerve injury since the patient has weakness in extending the middle finger and radial deviation on wrist extension. None of the other options would cause these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fracture and dislocation suggest possible injury to the radial nerve. The location of tenderness and weakness in extending the middle finger and deviation of the wrist indicate involvement of the posterior interosseous nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has weakness in extending the middle finger, which is innervated by the radial nerve. The radial nerve also innervates the muscles that control extension of the wrist, which explains the radial deviation on wrist extension. Based on the location of the tenderness and the previous history of a fracture with radial head dislocation, the most likely cause of the radial nerve injury is posterior interosseous nerve palsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with pain and weakness in the right forearm and hand, with specific weakness in extending her right middle finger. These symptoms are consistent with radial nerve dysfunction, and in particular, dysfunction of the posterior interosseous nerve, which supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm. The other options are less likely because they do not supply these specific muscles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a radial nerve injury, and among the options, the most likely nerve affected is the posterior interosseous nerve, which supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and is likely affected due to the surgical treatment of the previous fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient showed signs of radial deviation on extension of the wrist and weakness when extending her right middle finger, which suggests an extensor muscle involved. Posterior interosseous nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm, which includes the muscle that extends the middle finger. The ulnar nerve innervates the muscles of the hypothenar eminence and the medial two lumbricals; the anterior interosseous nerve innervates the flexor muscles of the forearm; the superficial radial nerve innervates the skin on the radial side of the forearm and dorsum of the hand.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the patient suggest posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) syndrome, which is caused by compression or injury of the PIN. The PIN supplies extensor muscles of the forearm, and weakness in extension of the middle finger indicates involvement of the PIN. The other options do not match the symptoms of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest posterior interosseous nerve entrapment, which can result from previous trauma or surgery in the area. The other options are less likely to cause these specific symptoms.
